ratioCategories.description: Measures the company's ability to meet short-term obligations using the 'Rev156' dataset [1].

ratios.name: Current Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Based on Source [1], the ratio of 2.01 indicates strong coverage of short-term liabilities. However, this version of the financials (Rev156) appears to classify all assets as Current Assets ($1,970,444), assuming zero fixed assets [2], which may artificially inflate this ratio compared to standard operations.

ratios.name: Quick Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Source [1] reports 0.63. This significant drop from the Current Ratio highlights that the majority of the company's liquidity is tied up in Inventory ($1.34M) [3], posing a risk if sales velocity slows.

ratios.name: Cash Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated using Cash of $155,134 [4] against Current Liabilities of $978,114 [1]. This indicates a reliance on inventory turnover and receivables collection to fund immediate obligations.

ratios.name: Working Capital
ratios.interpretation: Explicitly stated in Source [5]. The positive working capital is substantial, representing nearly 50% of Total Assets, primarily driven by the high inventory balance.

ratioCategories.description: Evaluates the company's ability to generate earnings relative to revenue and equity [6].

ratios.name: Gross Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Source [6] reports 22.73%. This is slightly below the typical 25-30% range for industrial equipment wholesalers, suggesting potential pressure on pricing or elevated Cost of Goods Sold.

ratios.name: Operating Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Source [6] reports 18.56%. This is exceptionally high for the industry. Note: This version of the financials (Rev156) appears to lack Depreciation expense [2], which significantly boosts operating income compared to versions that include it.

ratios.name: Net Profit Margin
ratios.interpretation: Source [6] reports 9.32% ($423,154 / $4.5M). This reflects a strong bottom line, although it is heavily influenced by the effective tax rate and the exclusion of depreciation in this specific reporting iteration.

ratios.name: Return on Assets (ROA)
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $423,154 / $1,970,444. Source [7] reports a higher 40.07% using Pre-Tax Income. Even at 21.47%, efficiency is high, but skewed by the asset base valuation (Zero Fixed Assets in Rev156 [2]).

ratios.name: Return on Equity (ROE)
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $423,154 / $532,118. Source [7] reports 148% using Pre-Tax figures. The extremely high ROE is a function of the thin equity base ($532k) relative to the debt load ($1.4M liabilities) [8].

ratios.name: EBITDA Margin
ratios.interpretation: Calculated using EBITDA of $789,577 [5]. Indicates strong operational cash generation potential before financial and tax impacts.

ratioCategories.description: Analyzes the company's use of debt and long-term solvency [1].

ratios.name: Debt-to-Equity Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Source [1] explicitly lists 2.70. This indicates high leverage; for every dollar of equity, the company owes $2.70 to creditors, increasing financial risk.

ratios.name: Debt-to-Assets Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Calculated from Liabilities $1,438,326 / Assets $1,970,444 [8]. 73% of the company's assets are financed by creditors, confirming the high-leverage position.

ratios.name: Interest Coverage Ratio
ratios.interpretation: Source [9] reports 11.93. Despite high debt, the strong Operating Income (EBIT) comfortably covers the interest expense of $66,186.

ratios.name: Equity Multiplier
ratios.interpretation: Calculated as $1,970,444 / $532,118. This multiplier amplifies the ROE but confirms that the company is trading on thin equity.

ratioCategories.description: Measures how effectively the company uses assets to generate sales [3].

ratios.name: Asset Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Source [7] reports 2.30. The company generates $2.30 in sales for every dollar of assets, indicating efficient asset utilization, though this is aided by the lack of capitalized fixed assets in this specific report [2].

ratios.name: Inventory Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Source [3] reports 2.61x. This is low for the sector, indicating inventory is held for long periods (approx 140 days [3]), suggesting potential overstocking or slow-moving parts/equipment.

ratios.name: Days Sales Outstanding
ratios.interpretation: Source [3] reports 37.42 days (Collection Period). This is better than the industry average, showing efficient collection of receivables.

ratios.name: Days Payable Outstanding
ratios.interpretation: Source [10] reports 49.30 days. The company takes longer to pay suppliers than it takes to collect from customers (37 days), which is favorable for cash flow management (negative cash conversion cycle component).

ratios.name: Accounts Receivable Turnover
ratios.interpretation: Source [3] reports 9.78x. This confirms strong credit management policies compared to peer benchmarks.

ratioCategories.description: Data Limitation: The source file 'Rev156-1' [4] cuts off the Cash Flow Statement and provides no specific Cash Flow data in the Ratios Schedule [1, 3, 5-7, 9-12]. Ratios below are strictly unavailable in the requested source.

ratios.name: Operating Cash Flow Ratio
ratios.interpretation: N/A - Source [4] cuts off before summarizing Operating Cash Flow. (Note: A separate draft [13] shows OCF of $338,686, which would yield a ratio of 0.34, but this contradicts the Net Income figures of the requested Rev156 file).

ratios.name: Free Cash Flow
ratios.interpretation: N/A - Source [4] does not provide CapEx or OCF data for this specific financial revision.

ratios.name: Cash Flow to Debt Ratio
ratios.interpretation: N/A - Essential Cash Flow data is missing from the provided text for file Rev156-3 [4].

overallAnalysis: Based strictly on the 'Rev156' dataset [1-12], NLTS-PR presents as a highly leveraged entity (Debt/Equity 2.70) with significant liquidity tied to Inventory (140 days sales on hand). While Profitability margins (Net Margin 9.32%) appear robust and above industry averages, this specific financial revision appears to exclude Depreciation expenses and Fixed Assets [2], which likely inflates reported efficiency and profitability metrics compared to standard GAAP presentation. The discrepancy between the high Operating Profit and the low Quick Ratio (0.63) suggests that while the company books sales effectively, cash is immediately reinvested into heavy inventory levels rather than liquid reserves.
